abstract.text: A mathematical ray you use to find 3D positions on real-world surfaces.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: You create a raycast query by providing a 3D vector and starting place.
To create a raycast query using a 2D screen location and default vector that casts outward in the z-direction from the user, use the convenience functions,
Raycasts can intersect with planes (flat surfaces) or meshes (uneven surfaces). To intersect with planes, see

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
A mathematical ray you use to find 3D positions on real-world surfaces.
The types of surface you allow a raycast to intersect with.
A raycast target that specifies nonplanar surfaces, or planes about which ARKit can only estimate.
A specification that indicates a target’s alignment with respect to gravity
A vector that describes the ray’s trajectory in 3D space.
Creates a new raycast query.
A 3D coordinate that defines the ray’s starting place.
A plane type that allows the raycast to terminate if it’s encountered.
The target’s alignment with respect to gravity.
Information about a real-world surface found by examining a point on the screen.
A view that blends virtual 3D content from SceneKit into your augmented reality experience.
Creates a raycast query that originates from a point on the view, aligned with the center of the camera’s field of view.
A raycast query that ARKit repeats in succession to give you refined results over time.
Place virtual content at tracked, real-world locations, and enable the user to interact with virtual content by using gestures.
A view that enables you to display an AR experience with RealityKit.
Creates a ray-cast query originating from a point in the view, centered on the camera’s field of view.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
